G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the events giving rise to this action occurred within the City of Worcester.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a property owner owes all lawful visitors a duty to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to remove or treat snow and ice hazards after reasonable notice and opportunity.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The court explicitly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and states that hazards from snow and ice are governed by the same reasonable care duty that applies to all other conditions for all lawful visitors. It also explains that liability turns on whether the owner knew or should have known of the dangerous snow/ice condition and had a reasonable opportunity to address it, aligning with the proposition’s reference to reasonable notice and opportunity to remove or treat such hazards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.” … “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7\u00a7 15 & 21.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining and inspecting the sidewalk abutting her property to prevent dangerous snow and ice accumulations.

Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining and inspecting the sidewalk abutting her property to prevent dangerous snow and ice accumulations.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.support_reasoning: The Sullivan v. Brookline opinion concerns the reinstatement of a disabled retiree police officer and the interaction of Massachusetts retirement and civil service statutes. It does not involve premises liability, sidewalk maintenance, or any duty regarding snow and ice on abutting sidewalks. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant owed a plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining and inspecting an abutting sidewalk for snow and ice hazards.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff, a twenty-year retiree of the Brookline police department (department), raises two issues through his petition for reinstatement: first, what standard should apply in evaluating a retiree’s fitness to return to full employment; and second, whether a long-term retiree must complete retraining before becoming entitled to reinstatement. To answer these questions this court must interpret G. L. c. 32, § 8 (2), and G. L. c. 31, § 39.

Collins v. Kenealy, 341 Mass. 49 (1960).proposition: Defendant breached that duty by failing to use reasonable care to eliminate or treat the icy condition after actual notice of its existence.
Collins v. Kenealy, 341 Mass. 49 (1960).case_name: The Salisbury Water Supply Co. v. Town of Salisbury
Collins v. Kenealy, 341 Mass. 49 (1960).support_reasoning: The opinion is a contracts/municipal authority case about a town’s power to enter into and pay for long‑term water supply extension contracts. It does not involve premises liability, ice, snow, or any duty of care to address an icy condition after notice. Because the decision never discusses negligence standards or duties to eliminate or treat ice, it does not support the proposition claimed.
Collins v. Kenealy, 341 Mass. 49 (1960).relevant_excerpt: The case concerns whether the town had authority to make and fund contracts with a water company: “Such town contracts to induce local public utilities to provide facilities for services to be furnished to the town and its inhabitants, where the services are to be paid for in part by the town currently from year to year, at least since Smith v. Dedham, 144 Mass. 177, may be regarded as within the express or implied contracting powers of towns.” There is no discussion of icy conditions or a duty to remedy them.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant was further negligent under the principles set forth in Papadopoulos, supra, and Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013), holding that landowners may be liable for accumulation of snow or ice when they fail to act reasonably in removing or addressing it.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses and applies Papadopoulos and § 343A to hold that a landowner may still owe a duty to remedy an open and obvious danger and can be liable when it is foreseeable that lawful entrants will encounter it despite the obvious risk. While Dos Santos itself involves a trampoline and shallow pool rather than snow and ice, it affirms the general Papadopoulos principle that landowners are not relieved from remedying open and obvious hazards when they should anticipate resulting harm, including in the snow-and-ice context cited in Papadopoulos. Thus the case supports the broader proposition that landowners may be liable for accumulations (of snow/ice or other open and obvious conditions) when they fail to act reasonably in addressing them.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg… Today, we consider the scope of a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger as contemplated in § 343A… our decision in Papadopoulos… explicitly reaffirmed our view that the existence of an open and obvious danger will not necessarily relieve a landowner of the duty to remedy that danger.”

Sweenor v. 162 State St., Inc., 361 Mass.raw_text: Sweenor v. 162 State St., Inc., 361 Mass. 524 (1972)
Sweenor v. 162 State St., Inc., 361 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s failure to apply salt, sand, or any deicing agent after clearing only a narrow path constituted unreasonable maintenance under Sweenor v. 162 State St., Inc., 361 Mass. 524 (1972).
Sweenor v. 162 State St., Inc., 361 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a bar owner’s duty to protect patrons from injuries caused by an intoxicated, boisterous customer and whether it was foreseeable that such a patron might fall and injure someone. It says nothing about snow/ice, deicing agents, or the reasonableness of clearing and treating an icy path. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition about failure to apply salt, sand, or deicer constituting unreasonable maintenance.
Sweenor v. 162 State St., Inc., 361 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant, as the operator of a restaurant and bar, was in possession of real estate open to the public for business purposes. It owed a duty to a paying patron to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional. Restatement 2d: Torts, § 344… It was open to the jury in the instant case to determine whether the defendant failed to conform to this duty by failing to restrain or remove the boisterous patron, and by continuing to serve him liquor.”

Bernard v. H.J. Richard & Sons, Inc., 34.raw_text: Bernard v. H.J. Richard & Sons, Inc., 344 Mass. 163 (1962)
Bernard v. H.J. Richard & Sons, Inc., 34.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the hazard when tenants communicated the dangerous condition, making her failure to act a breach of duty under Bernard v. H.J. Richard & Sons, Inc., 344 Mass. 163 (1962).
Bernard v. H.J. Richard & Sons, Inc., 34.case_name: Aetna Casualty & Surety Co. v. Harvard Trust Co.
Bernard v. H.J. Richard & Sons, Inc., 34.support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial surety/priority-of-assignments case and does not involve premises liability, tenants, or landlord notice of physical hazards. Its discussion of ‘notice’ concerns whether a financing bank had notice of prior assignments or contractor default, not notice of a dangerous condition communicated by tenants. Therefore it does not establish or apply any rule that a defendant’s actual notice of a hazard via tenant complaints creates a breach of duty, and it cannot properly be cited for that proposition.
Bernard v. H.J. Richard & Sons, Inc., 34.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that there is no claim to recover the payments made to Harvard prior to February 3, 1958, which Aetna as surety may now enforce. This view does not disregard the inchoate equity of subrogation or fail to give effect to the conditional assignment to the surety... It does require proof that an assignee or creditor, receiving payment otherwise in good faith, had actual knowledge that the contractor had committed a material breach, before the surety’s equity will be enforced against that payment.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: The risk of harm from refreezing was foreseeable, and Defendant’s decision to rely on “the sun” to cure the condition violated the standard of ordinary care articulated in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard concerns the abandonment of common-law status distinctions between licensees and invitees and briefly discusses the treatment of trespassers. It does not address foreseeability of refreezing, the risk of harm from icy conditions, or any standard of care involving reliance on the sun to cure ice. Therefore, this citation does not support the specific proposition about foreseeability of refreezing and breach of ordinary care in that context.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and subsequent injuries within the meaning of Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether the defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Jupin v. Kask addresses only duty and foreseeability in the context of negligence and reverses summary judgment so a jury can consider breach and causation; it does not hold that the defendant’s negligence was a direct or proximate cause of the harm. Thus, the case cannot be cited as authority that negligence was a direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were reasonably foreseeable, and no independent, superseding cause intervened.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk created by Lombardo’s negligence, which is the opposite of the claimed proposition. By concurring in the court’s view on foreseeability, the opinion rejects the notion that the injuries were reasonably foreseeable, and thus does not support—indeed, it contradicts—the proposition that no independent, superseding cause intervened and that the injuries were foreseeable.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Carey v. Malley, 327 Mass. 189 (1951).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for these losses.
Carey v. Malley, 327 Mass. 189 (1951).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns landlord liability for injuries from ice and snow and procedural issues about verdicts; it does not discuss the measure of damages or state that a plaintiff is entitled to recover “fair and reasonable compensation” for losses. The decision is about whether the landlord can be held liable at all, not about the standard for calculating or awarding damages. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific compensation proposition cited.
